title: 109_s3977
content: Reduced taxes for Patriot Employers under section 45N of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Patriot employer credit under section 45N of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a tax credit equal to 1 percent of taxable income for certified Patriot employers. A Patriot employer is defined as a taxpayer that maintains its headquarters in the United States, pays at least 60 percent of employee health care premiums, and employs at least 50 employees on average during the taxable year. The Patriot employer credit under section 45N of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a tax credit equal to 1 percent of taxable income for certified Patriot employers. To qualify, a taxpayer must maintain its headquarters in the United States, pay at least 60 percent of employee health care premiums, and employ at least 50 employees on average during the taxable year. Additionally, the taxpayer must meet certain criteria such as maintaining or increasing the number of full-time workers in the United States, compensating employees at a certain hourly rate, and providing a defined contribution plan with specific requirements. The employer must make contributions to employees' defined contribution plans based on a percentage of their compensation, with specific requirements for non-highly compensated employees. The employer must make contributions to employees' defined contribution plans based on a percentage of their compensation, with specific requirements for non-highly compensated employees, including providing differential salary and insurance benefits for National Guard and Reserve employees called for active duty. Employers with less than 50 employees must compensate each employee at a rate not less than the Federal poverty level. The employer must make contributions to employees' defined contribution plans based on a percentage of their compensation, with specific requirements for non-highly compensated employees. This includes providing a defined contribution plan that requires the employer to make contributions of at least 5 percent of compensation for each employee who is not a highly compensated employee. The employer must make contributions to employees' defined contribution plans based on a percentage of their compensation, with specific requirements for non-highly compensated employees. This includes providing a defined benefit plan that requires contributions of at least 5 percent of compensation for each non-highly compensated employee. The Patriot employer credit is added as a general business credit under the Internal Revenue Code, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2006.
